question: Drug of choice for treatment of intermediate uveitis is
exp: Treatment for Intermediate uveitis: Intravitreal or Posterior Subtenon's Steroid injections: Triamcinolone acetonide Steroids may also be given by subconjuntival route or by Subtenon's route

question: Vitreous floaters are seen in
exp: Choroiditis refers to inflammation of the choroid which in most cases also involves the adjacent retina resulting in chorioretinitis. clinical features: -Painless visual symptoms like photopsia -Vitreous Floaters: black spots in front of the eyes - represent the vitreous inflammation - opacities that cast shadows on the retina - can be seen in any condition associated with vitritis - intermediate or posterior uveitis -Micropsia or macropsia -Positive scotoma Fundus examination reveals vitreous opacities with active healed stage of retinitis. Treated by systemic steroids

question: All the drugs are used in acute anterior uveitis except?
exp: Treatment of anterior uveitis: 1) Topical steroids are the Drug of choice Side effect: - Topical steroids - Glaucoma - Systemic steroids - Cataract Topical steroids: - Betamethasone - Dexamethasone - most commonly used, causes significant IOP rise and hence glaucoma(after difluprednate) - Prednisolone - Fluorometholone, Loteprednol - cause minimum glaucoma(hence called soft steroids) - Difluprednate - lower frequency of dosing butmaximum propensity to cause glaucoma 2) Cycloplegics - Atropine - 14 days action (most potent) - Homatropine - 3 days action - Cyclopentolate - 1 day action - Tropicamide - 6 hrs action ( least potent) - Cycloplegics are used to reduce pain by relaxes ciliary spasm. - Timolol eye drops are used to manage secondary intraocular pressure rise (secondary glaucoma) in a case of uveitis - Pilocarpine causes increased vascular leakage and can worsen symptoms of uveitis. Hence Pilocarpine use for other indications may mimic anterior uveitis

question: A 25 year - old female gives a history of redness, pain and mild diminution of vision in one eye for past 3 days. There is also a history of low backache for the past one year. On examination there is circumcorneal congestion, cornea is clear apa from a few fine keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium, there are 2+ cells in the anterior chamber, anterior chamber depth being normal and the intraocular pressure is within normal limits. The patient is most likely suffering from:
exp: History of backache with features of anterior uveitis(circumcorneal congestion, few fine keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium, 2+ cells in the anterior chamber )point towards HLA B27 associated uveitis. Seronegative spondyloahropathies-all are HLA B-27 positive. Sacrolitis (low back pain ) is earliest manifestation. M/C Extra Aicular Manifestation- Uveitis JIA(Juvenile Idiopathic Ahritis)- It usually develops before the age of 6 years. Pauciaicular, ANA positive, RF negative In 75% of Patients suffering from JIA associated with anterior uveitis have antinuclear antibodies (ANA) positive (HIGHEST association) In 50% of Patients suffering from JIA associated with anterior uveitis have predisposition due to HLA-DW5
opa: Acute attack of angle closure glaucoma

question: Dalen fuch nodule is seen in?
exp: Dalen fuch's nodules seen in Sympathetic Ophthalmitis. -Collection of epitheloid histocytes between Bruch's membrane and Retinal pigment epithelium (i. e. sub retinal or choroidal location) -Seen as punctacte white spots in mid-periphery in deep retina (retinal vessels seen to run over the lesions)

question: Koeppe's and Busaca's nodules are characteristic of
exp: Presentation of anterior uveitis: - Iris nodules: a) Koeppe's nodules - present on pupillary margin b) Busacca's nodules - present on surface of iris Both are seen in granulomatous uveitis

question: Atropine 1% is given in uveitis to:
exp: Atropine is antimuscranic(Anticholinergic) and ciliary body is supplied by Parasympthetic System Sho Ciliary Nerve (3 rd ciliary nerve). hence, Atropine (Cyclpplegic) Relaxes Ciliary Spasm Doc- for immediate pain releif. Dilates the Pupil, thus prevents the synchae Formation, breaks the synchiae already being formed Reduces vascularity
opa: Cause mydriasis and prevention of posterior synechiae
opb: Cause miosis and prevention of anterior synechiae
opc: Cause mydriasis and prevention of anterior synechiae
opd: Cause miosis and prevention of posterior synechiae

question: All are causes of chronic granulomatous uveitis except:
exp: Fuchs iridocyclitis (Fuchs Heterochromic Uveitis): Almost always U/L uveitis Young age Idiopathic TRIAD: - Heterochromia - Cataract - Diffuse Stellate KP's Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis presents with low grade anterior or intermediate uveitis and no remarkable symptoms Usually identified during routine examination/cataract evaluation in young/glaucoma evaluation Commonly associated with Glaucoma

question: Which of the following is the commonest infectiuos cause for posterior uveitis?
exp: Toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of posterior uveitis and accounts for around approximately 90 % of focal necrotizing retinitis. causitive agent - Toxoplasmosis gondi. H/O - contact with cat faeces C/F - Vitritis with underlying white-yellow choroiditis patch - 'Headlight in Fog Appearance" other causes of Posterior Uveitis:- Infections toxoplasmois TB(2nd M/C/CAUSE) Toxocariasis CMV, HIV Immune Disorders Sarcodiais PAN Sclroderma

question: The use of highly active anti-retroviral therapy (HAA) is associated with the development of:
exp: Immune Recovery Uveitis With initiation of HAA, there is an upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-2, IL-6 and TNF alfa and the T lymphocycte fraction (increase to range of 100 cells/mm3). Present understanding is that with increase in the body's mechanism to mount an immune response, the body mounts a response to previously quiet and hence undiagnosed oppounistic infections such as CMV retinitis. Clinical manifestations can be varied and most commonly involves the posterior segment of the eye, though anterior, intermediate uveitis are also repoed. Papillitis may also be a feature.

question: Snow banking on fundus examination is the sign of
exp: Pars planitis is intermediate uveitis M /c cause of pars planitis is idiopathic M/c symptom is FLOATERS Eye is usually quiet, fundus shows Snow ball opacities which may join together to form Snow banking. (Hallmark Feature) Snow Balls-are the infllamatory cells From Pars Plana thrown into vitreous causing vitreous floaters. these gravitate and sink down fotming Snow Banking.

question: All of the following cause panuveitis except?
exp: Panuveitis. It is inflammation of all pas of the uveal tract - i. e. iris, ciliary body and choroid, manifestations of which can be seen in both the anterior (anterior chamber + posterior chamber) and posterior (vitreous cavity) segment of the eye. Cause of Panuveitis Sarcodiosis Tuberculosis Syphils Onchocerciasis Leptospirosis Brucelliosis Sympthetic Opthalmia Bechets's diseas Multiple Sclerosis Cysticercosis Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada Syndrome Retinal itraneuclear foreign body Masquerade syndrome: retinoblastoma, leukemia Ankylosing spondylitis causes anterior uveitis. (Seronegative ahropathy)

question: In a patient with AIDS, chorioretinitis is typically caused by
exp: Commonest ocular infection in HIV patient - CMV retinitis Bush- Fire appeareance Pizza- Pie Appearance Sauce & Cheese Appearance OCULAR HIV: - M/C ocular manifestation - Cotton wool spot or soft exudate or HIV retinopathy - M/C occular infection - CMV retinitis - M/C occular tumor - kaposi sarcoma > Lymphoma
